awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Dynamic Response of the Soil Production Function to Erosion Rates
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT
A non-technical description of the project, which explains the project's significance and importance

The formation of soil and its removal from the landscape are two of the most important geological processes that intersect with the livelihood and well-being of human populations. Soil is needed for agriculture, and the characteristics of this material affect the availability of groundwater and the ecological balance of different landscapes. Erosion can be very damaging and the rate at which material is transported to streams will have an impact on flooding. This project will examine the rate at which soil is produced and eroded in order to better assess the controls on the distribution of this very important natural resource.

A technical description of the project

Soil thickness is a fundamentally important characteristic of the Earth's surface that plays an essential role in hydrology, ecology, biogeochemistry, erosion, and transport processes. The prevailing theory predicts that mean soil thickness decreases with increasing catchment-mean erosion rate and that soil-mantled landscapes give way to rocky ones when this erosion rate exceeds the climate- and lithology-controlled maximum soil production rate. However, initial observations indicate that soil thickness is much more variable across otherwise similar landscapes than can be explained by this theory.  This project will use a combination of in situ and detrital cosmogenic radionuclide analyses and digital elevation models across a suite of carefully selected field sites to quantify the fundamental influences on soil thickness in geologically active regions.

por.por_cntn:
This project was funded to test the hypothesis that soil production rates may actually increase with catchment-mean erosion rates, a concept advanced by the Heimsath et al. (2012) Nature Geosciencepaper. This hypothesis has fundamental, unexplored consequences for landscape response to active uplift, with impacts on theoretical understanding of how the biota, soils, hydrology, erosion and transport processes modify landscape form. The greatest impetus for pursuing this previously untested hypothesis is that a couple decades of thinking about soil production processes in landscape evolution need to be overturned if the hypothesis is clearly supported. To support this hypothesis, we suggest that the frequency and/or intensity of disturbances at a given depth below the ground surface increases with catchment-mean erosion rate due to the commensurate increase in the frequency of processes such as new root growth, tree throw, and mass wasting events.The project was modest, funding field work, sample collection and analyses of a suite of samples collected across a range of erosion rates in the San Bernardino Mountains of California. 

 

The primary outcome of this project is the complete analysis of a set of samples that quantify soil production rates beneath a full range of soil thicknesses and from areas of the landscape eroding rapidly (steep) and slowly (gentle). Our results show strong support for our hypothesis, as well as for the results first presented to forward this provocative idea in 2012 (see figure). Specifically, thirteen samples from the more rapidly eroding parts of the landscape define a soil production function (black dashed line) that is markedly steeper, with a significantly higher soil production rate efficiency than the soil production function defined by six samples from the more slowly part of the landscape (green dashed line). Average erosion rates from the two areas of the landscape are correspondingly high (red circles to the right of the main data) and low (blue circles). 

 

Because these data so clearly support the provocative hypothesis posed by this project we are drafting a high impact manuscript articulating the full findings of this project and will be presenting these results at international meetings in the coming year.
